description.narrative: Development Advisory Services for direct support to upstream initiatives in UNDP's focus areas.
Development Advisory Services are established to provide Resident Representative with a rapid response capacity for direct support to upstream initiatives in UNDP's main focus areas.
independent political entity
The Country Programme of Albania under the Global Solar Water Heating Market Transformation and Strengthening Initiative (PIMS 3611)

title.narrative: Programme of Albania for market strengthening and acceleration to promote solar water heating in Albania

description.narrative: Legal and regulatory framework on Global Solar Water Heating market created Enhanced awareness and capacity on SWH Increased demand for SWH by the availability of financing mechanisms Developed certification and quality control scheme
capital of a political entity
The total installed SWH capacity and annual sale.

comment.narrative: 33,000 m2 of installed collector area in 2005 with 7,000 m2 of new SWH capacity installed in 2005 with the expected 5% annual growth.

The adoption of the recommended legal and regulatory changes to promote sustainable SWH market development. Materials for public awareness raising as well as for training of building designers developed and/or adapted into Albanian conditions and made available in printed and electronic format. Enhanced awareness of the key financial sector stakeholder and local suppliers on the specific characteristics and financing opportunities in the SWH market. A certification and quality control scheme applicable for Albanian conditions and enhanced capacity of the supply chain to offer products and services promoting sustainable SWH market. The reporting framework and arrangement for the SWH market monitoring established.

Efforts during reporting period have been focused on supporting Ministry of Energy and Industry to progress with finalization of the RES Action Plan (with a specific target for solar energy), revision of RES Law/its secondary legislation to implement the Solar Chapter; supporting municipalities of Tirana, Elbasan, Shkoder, Sarande, Orikum, Gramsh and Fier with technical assistance and demonstration projects to justify the solar obligation’s ordinances to request SWH systems in each and every new public building and the ones going through a major renovation; on the job trainings for monitoring and maintenance of installed solar thermal systems; monitoring programs for hot water consumption and efficiency of big SWH systems; efforts to detail the EE/RES fund or other financing models, like NAMAs; opening of the assistance in the area of standards for EE and solar energy in social buildings, etc. A series of capacity building activities and awareness raising held on technology of SWH with several municipalities/communes alongside the south coast of Albania; During the reported period different promotion materials such as leaflets, fast facts, posters, 2015 wall calendar are prepared and distributed; Project webpage was transferred to UNDP’s one (www.al.undp.org) updated on regularly bases, while project’s activities were shared to some other social medias like Facebook, twitter, etc. Regular articles written and published to several newspapers and magazines.

description.narrative: Regional Level Governance and Local Development - Art Gold 2 (ARTiculation of territorial and thematic networks of human development cooperation)

title.narrative: ART 2013 Annual Report UNDP ART GOLD 2 ALBANIA
Third Party Cost Sharing Agreement with Friuli Venezia Giulia
Mid-Term Evaluation: ART GOLD 2 Programme in Albania

description.narrative: Capacities of national & local government actors is strengthened in elaborating, implementing and monitoring County Strategic Plans in an integrated approach to improve competitiveness and sustainable development, drawing on international partnerships.
seat of a first-order administrative division
seat of a first-order administrative division
Accountability - local government finance

(a) The extent to which evidence and consultations with all relevant stakeholders contribute to the development of locally owned strategic development plans for the counties of Shkodra and Vlora. (b) No. of activities initiated in Vlora and Shkodra which address priorities identified during the strategic planning process. (c) No. of local SMEs LEDAs provide with integrated services addressing their financing, production and marketing needs. (d) Degree to which the debate on sustainable local development in Albania contributes to and draws on international best practice.

comment.narrative:
(a1) Limited support for the territorial approach to development. (a2) No strategic integrated development plans in place for Vlora or Shkodra. (a3) Limited capacities and resources of regional and central government structures to design and implement strategic development plans at county level.
(b) Limited efforts to improve and valorise the endogenous development potential of Vlora and Shkodra.
(c1) Limited capacities of small business enterprises to compile business plans and be able to attract investments and make use of bank loans. (c2) Lack of functional chains of value for endogenous products resulting in difficulties to reach domestic and international markets and establish recognized brands. (c3) Limited capacities of local economic development agencies (LEDAs) to offer integrated services to existing small and medium enterprises and the start-up of new ones.
(d) Limited capacities of Albanian universities and other research institutes to conduct and implement research and research-oriented action on recognizing innovative local practices in economic and human development.

(b10) The two initiatives implemented in cooperation with Friuli-Venezia Giulia region, i.e. Hotel Villages promoting mountainous tourism and “Marubi Visual Museum”, are successfully completed
(c5) Cooperation with and support to LEDAs is strengthened through joint involvement in local, national and international projects of cooperation

Target (b10) has been achieved. The Hotel Villages has been implemented through the traditional restoration and tourist friendly improvement of six guesthouses of traditional architecture in the Albanian Alps and training of 25 local residents in tourism operation and foreign languages. The “Marubi Visual Museum” has launched its public website for retrieving photos from its archives and along the year over 100 thousand negatives have been catalogued and digitized and the process will expand in 2016.
Re target (c5) UNDP continued to support AULEDA in Vlora and TEULEDA in Shkoder through engaging them in project activities related to local development and promoting their networking and partnership; for instance AULEDA was supported to participate and share its local experience with an international audience in the Third World Forum on Local Economic Development held in Turin in October 2015.

description.narrative: Improving coverage and management effectiveness of marine and coastal protected areas (PIMS 4255)

title.narrative: Mid-Term Review of Improving coverage and management effectiveness in marine and coastal protected areas project

description.narrative: Improved bio-geographical representation of MCPAs Improved management arrangements for MCPAs based on clear institutional responsibilities and development of capacities.
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Strategic Plan for Albania’s Marine and Coastal Protected Areas 2. Two proposals for new MPA establishment 3. Legal environment for MCPA management 4. Adequate management of buffer zone for MPA 5. Guideline for adequate management of buffer zone for MCPA 6. Management Boards at MCPAs 7. # of agreements or memorandum of cooperation/ understanding MPA/PA issues 8. Management effectiveness tools for MCPAs 9. Number of manuals/ guidebooks prepared as a resource for imparting further training 10. Funding of Karaburuni-Sazani MPA 11. Status of the seagrass Posidonia oceanica along Karaburuni and Albanian Ionian coast

comment.narrative: No Strategy for Marine Protected Areas No Management Board at MPA No Management Effectiveness tool for MCPAs in place

1. Public hearing and participatory process for the approval of the Management Plan for Karaburun-Sazani 2. Implementing priority management actions according to the Management Plan for Karaburun-Sazani 3. Production of the Business Plan for Karaburun-Sazani 4. Assist MPA Administration in enforcement and control mechanism through Micro Capital Agreement arrangement with local institutions and NAPA 5. Strengthening of the MPA administration with training and equipment 6. Assistance of the MoE for the new MPA designation, Porto Palermo 7. Produce a booklet with information on MCAPs 8. Produce of the Manual of Training of Trainers on MCPAs management 9. Training on management effectiveness and produce an online tracking tool on management effectiveness 10. Production of the photo album on Karaburun-Sazani MPA

1. Public hearing and participatory process for the approval of the Management Plan for Karaburun-Sazani is completed. 2. Micro Capital Agreement arrangements with local institutions and NAPA are signed to assist MPA Administration in enforcement 3. Equipment for MPA administration are provided. 4. Assistance of the MoE for the new MPA designation, Porto Palermo is provided. 5. Booklet with information on MCAPs is produced 6. Manual of Training of Trainers on MCPAs management is produced 7. Application online on tracking tool on management effectiveness is produced and provided.

description.narrative: To improve coverage and management effectiveness of Albaniaâ€™s marine and coastal protected areas.
Area under protection as Coastal and Marine Protected Areas

comment.narrative:
100,236 ha
(existing coastal protected areas - mainly coastal wetlands)

An additional 12,570.82 ha declared as Albaniaâ€™s first MPA (Karaburun Sazani)
An additional 3,500 ha in the process of being declared as MPAs (Rodoni Cape-Lalzi Bay and Pagane-Kepi i Stillos)

Two other MCPA, Porto Palermo (and Cape of Rodoni are in the process to be proclaimed. Public hearing are organizes and respective reporting are delivered. The draft Decision of Council of Ministers for Porto Palermo foresees the status Natural Park for a surface of 2,067.75 ha. It is planned to be proclaimed within 2015.

description.narrative: Enabling environment created for revision of the existing MCPA status, facilitated by the project

comment.narrative: Weak capacities for revising MCPAs status
At least 2 MoE experts capable for conducting revision of MCPA according the international standards.

Training curricula and modules on marine biodiversity conservation and management are developed.
Training workshops have been organized involving more than 45 local specialists, MCPA administration, as well as 5 experts from the MoE.
A Manual on Training on Integrated Management of MCPAs is published.

description.narrative: Improvement in management effectiveness of Karaburuni-Sazani MPA measured through change in METT scores

comment.narrative: Baseline METT Score as percent of Total Possible Score is 17%
Target is 45-55%

METT assessment report accomplished on 16th December 2014 through e regional training workshop in Divjaka PA. METT assessment is accomplished for all coastal PAs
The score for MPA Karaburun-Sazani, increased from 39 to 45 attesting for the efforts made in enforcement and management of the site.
The project is developing a user friendly electronic format for METT (web based)

description.narrative: Increased Systemic, Institutional and Individual capacities for establishing and managing an MCPA system

comment.narrative:
See UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard in Annex 5 for baseline
Systemic - 37%
Institutional - 29%
Individual - 38%

See UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard in Annex 5 for target
Systemic - 90%
Institutional - 87%
Individual - 95%

Systematic 40%, 67%
Institutional 36% 58%
Individual 43% 57%
Compared with 2014, UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard for MCPA, shows an increase of 27% for systematic, 22% for institutional and 14% for individual level. There are development in legislation, strategies and programmes. A new institution is established, National Agency for Protected Areas, which shows the political will towards Protected Areas and will help on building consensus among all institutions and stakeholders, capacity to mobilize information and knowledge and capacity to monitor, evaluate, report and learn. Compared to the baseline there is an increase of about 30 %.

description.narrative: Improved bio-geographical representation of marine and coastal protected areas (MCPA)
Strategic Plan for Albaniaâ€™s Marine and Coastal Protected Areas (SPMCPA)

comment.narrative: No Strategic Plan has been developed for this sub-system of the national PA system
SPMCPA is developed and approved by the Inter-ministerial Council or the Council of Ministers
The updated “Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan” is approved by the government and the SPMCPA is taken into consideration and incorporated in the document.

description.narrative: Legal Instrument establishing MPA at Karaburuni-Sazani (12,570.82 ha.)

comment.narrative: No Legal Instrument
Legal Instrument is approved by the Council of Ministers

The law on biodiversity is revised.
A new law on PA is under development, accomplishing a combined review of all legal acts pertinent to environment conservation and management, possible models/ mechanisms for MCPA administration, revenues mechanisms, changes with establishment of NAPA – National Agency for Protected Areas as the biggest institutional development taking over the management of PA with direct dependence from the Minster of Environment, splitting the management of protected areas form the forestry service structure

description.narrative: Legal Instrument incorporates best practice in design of such an instrument and can serve as a model for declaration of future MPAs

comment.narrative: There are no MPAs in Albania and, therefore, no examples of a legal instrument establishing an MPA
Legal Instrument for Karaburuni-Sazani MPA is developed as a model for future MPAs

The roadmap is prepared for the MCPA legal frame and recommendations to improve legislation and approximate it with EU directive.
In additions the PA law is paying due attention on all latest institutional progress and development of relevant sector (tourism activities, zoning, enforcement, environmental inspectorates, fisheries inspectorates, the Coast Guard, etc.)

description.narrative: Clearly demarcated buffer zones in Karaburuni-Sazani MPA, with specific guidance on permissible activities included in the Management Plan

comment.narrative: No buffer zones defined
Buffer zones and permissible activities defined

Assessment report on marine and coastal areas buffer zone is finalized, including guidelines/ recommendations on setting up buffer zones for MPAs.
The integrated management planning process (Karaburuni - Sazani) developed with significant participatory approach has considered the buffer zone.

description.narrative: Clearly demarcated buffer zones in existing 9 coastal PAs, with specific guidance on permissible activities for inclusion in the Management Plan

comment.narrative:
No buffer zones defined
No Management Plans in place.
Buffer zones and permissible activities defined

The management planning for the MPA Karaburun - Sazani and the buffer zoning roadmap are developed. Buffer zone protocols and rules are being provided as respective management arrangements.
In addition the management plan for Porto Palermo MPA has also developed the site zoning and site boundaries with due attention in the buffer area as well. The zoning process has started in the meantime for the Cape of Rodoni.

description.narrative: Process of identification of additional MPAs at Rodoni Cape-Lalzi Bay and Pagane-Kepi i Stillos has begun.

comment.narrative: Currently the adjacent areas have a protection status as CPAs only.
Technical and scientific work for realizing designation of these areas is complete, and political consultation process has been initiated

Processes for the designation of two additional MPAs: Porto Palermo and Cape of Rodoni are progressing well. According to the SPMCPA, the two priority areas to be proclaimed are Porto Palermo (not Pagan Kepi Stillos) and Rodoni Cape.
Ecologic evaluation, public hearing organized with MoE, relevant document for designating these sites, as well as meetings with local stakeholders, including informative materials and posters are accomplished.
The draft Decision of Council of Ministers for Porto Palermo foresees the status Natural Park for a surface of 2,067.75 ha. It is planned to be proclaimed within 2015.

description.narrative: Improved management arrangements for MCPAs based on clear institutional responsibilities and development of capacities
Management Boards at MCPAs

comment.narrative: At least 2 MCPAs have Management Boards

2 +
There is organized another MC meeting during reporting period (5th MC, 27 January 2015) focusing and discussing the site management plan, project progress, main problems and other progress (mainly management plan document and priority actions), as well as financial issues. The project plan for 2015 is discussed and approved at the Management Committee.

description.narrative: Inter-institutional agreements on management of marine and land-based threats to MCPAs

comment.narrative: At least 2 official agreements or memorandum of cooperation/ understanding between relevant ministries/institutions

2 +
MoU are continuing to be implemented with the Municipality of Orikumi and Regional Agency of PA with focus collection data and info on illegal activities.
Monthly reports by Municipality of Orikum and Regional Agency of PA deliver to the Ministry of Environment.
MoU/ Micro capital Grant Agreement with an Albanian NGO (INCA) is in place for the implementation of priority actions in Karaburun-Sazani MPA as per management plan.
Cooperation and synergies include Prefecture of Vlora, Commune Center, Regional Directory of Environment of Vlora, Coastline National Agency, NGOs.
Synergies and logistic are ensured with National Agency for Protected Areas, NAPA (recently established, February 2015) for the protection and conservation of marine biodiversity.

description.narrative: Management effectiveness of existing 9 CPAs is being tracked

comment.narrative: Baseline METT Scores as percent of Total Possible Score to be estimated by the end of 2nd year
Progress in METT scores assessed annually thereafter

9 +
Regional training workshop on METT accomplished on 16th December 2014.
METT assessment results are:
PN Korab Korit. - 44%
Shebenik - 67%
NP Lure - 44%
NP LLogara –67%
Bize Martanesh -44%
NP Valbona - 67%
NP Tomorri - 67%
NP Kune Vaini 56%
Porto Palermo - 44%
NP Mali i Dajtit - 67%
NP Karavasta - 78%
Fushe Kuqe Ishem-67%
NP Hotove - 56%
The score for MPA Karaburun-Sazani, increased from 39 to 45 attesting for the efforts made in enforcement and management of the site.
The project is developing a user friendly electronic format for METT

description.narrative: Number of manuals/ guidebooks prepared as a resource for imparting further training

comment.narrative: Very limited
6 training modules

6 +
Training curricula and modules on marine biodiversity conservation and management are developed. A number of trainings and workshop has been organized during 2013-2014, involving more than 45 local specialists, MCPA administration, as well as 5 experts from the MoE. The final training workshop was held on August 2014
A Manual on Training on Integrated Management of MCPAs is published.
Other publications are on the way include buffer zone guideline, a passport for the Albanian MCPA, and a photo album for Karaburun-Sazani MPA values.

description.narrative: Gap between funding needs of Karaburuni-Sazani MPA and available funds

comment.narrative: Gap to be assessed by end of 1st year
At least 50% of funding needs are being met.

The priority actions taken from the MP document are duly addresses. A Micro Capital Grant Agreement is signed with INCA addressing the financial gap in funding priority management actions of the MCPA Karaburun-Sazani which will capture, design and establish the buoys system, repair and maintenance of some moles, drafting and implement the code of conduct for the observation of wildlife, updating inventory and monitoring of caves, assess the situation of underwater objects, fishing capacity assessment, awareness packages and tourist products, training, etc.
The Business Plan for MPA Karaburun-Sazani is under preparation.
The NAPA has meantime sustained the government efforts and is providing government funds for accomplishing management action and conservation measures at MCPA Karaburun-Sazani.

description.narrative: Increased understanding of the fish resources of the MPA

comment.narrative: Very limited studies on fish resources for the targeted area (s)
At least 3 site diagnoses missions and reports for K-S MCPA, deep insights fishery cross-sectorial studies scoping the management and conservation of this sector

3
There are three mission accomplished in cooperation with Conservatoire du Littoral assessing the habitats and species on the target area including fish populations.
The reports are delivered and taken into consideration for the Management Plan preparation of MPA Karaburun-Sazani.

description.narrative: Aware inhabitants and stakeholders adjacent to the MPA (and countrywide) of MBD values

comment.narrative:
No means and tools available at local level to deliver information to stakeholders.
No media coverage and no website for the targeted site. Local media (radio and TV) has never run programme on MCPA and /or MBD values).

At least 3 dedicated programmes on MCPA and MBD conservation are mediatised per year.by EoY 5.
All school children in Orikumi and Vlora are fully aware of globally important biodiversity in the K-S MCPA by EoY 5.

3 +
There have been produce a short documentary for the MPA site, and several public awareness activities (celebration of significand days such as 22nd May, 2nd February, 5 June, etc.) The Environment Film Festival has conducted its 3rd edition in Albania. The project has been actively part focusing on marine biodiversity films and involving the local schools.
Awareness campaign is being conducted as part of implementation of the Management Plan in Karaburun-Sazani MPA.
Knowledge and information is also produced and delivered in scope of new MPA designation processes (Porto Palermo and Cape of Rodoni through workshops and posters).

title.narrative: PIMS 4467 Albania Third National Communication to UNFCCC

description.narrative: PIMS 4467 CC EA Self-Assessment TNC Albania

title.narrative: PIMS 4467 Albania Third National Communication to UNFCCC

description.narrative: The objectives of the TNC are to enable Albania to enhance available GHG emission data, perform targeted research, and strengthen technical capacity and institutions to address GHG inventory, GHG mitigation and adaptation to climate change.
independent political entity
(A) Publication of the TNC. (B) Building institutional capacity in Albania for education, training and public awareness related to climate change.

comment.narrative: to update the annual Albanian Inventory of Anthropogenic GHGs to the period 2000-2009, focusing on the sectors/gases that have a significant share of GHG emissions such as the transport sector; downscaled global models will be developed to regionalize climate projections and apply in Vulnerability and Adaptation assessments that are focused on the entire coastal region; state-of-the-art GHG mitigation modeling frameworks will be used to developed a national low carbon development strategy. Albania’s description of national circumstances will be updated, as well as the steps to be taken or envisaged to implement the Convention. Finally, the project will continue to build institutional capacity for implementing the Convention in Albania including undertaking activities related to climate change education and awareness.

The GHG emissions inventories for 2000-2009 from 5 economic sectors drafted, discussed, peer-reviewed and finalized; Climate Change scenarios finalized; Vulnerability analysis and the adaptation plan for coastal area of Albania developed, peer-reviewed, discussed and finalized; the mitigation analysis till 2030 developed, discussed and finalized; the mitigation scenarios for the energy sector calibrated in close cooperation with SEI-Boston, the author of LEAP software; the TNC report under the drafting process.

title.narrative: Albanian Mine Action and Ammunition Disposal

description.narrative: Coordination and monitoring of humanitarian mine action, hotspots clearance and ammunition stockpile disposal in Albania

title.narrative: Third Party Cost Sharing Agreement with Germany

description.narrative: The project is aiming to improve ammunition disposal and clearance standards through coordination and monitoring of clearance of the ammunition hotspots.
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

Improved EOD and quality management standards in line with the International Mine Action Standards.
A public awareness and risk education scheme running in the affected areas.
A victim assistance system in place to encompass all ERW/AXO survivors.

comment.narrative: The current government demilitarization plan is running solely as a military operation without considerations on safety measures and socio-economic impact on civilian population.

Certification and handover of about 400,000 sqm of cleared UXO/ERW hotspots in Gjeroven, Palikesht and Mbreshtan in Berat, Klos and Suç in Diber, Gerdec and Laç. About 28,000 community members living around the highly contaminated hotspots are educated and aware about the ammunition threat. About 100 amputee survivors are fitted with either new prostheses or repairs and needs and status of at least 80% of ERW/AXO victims throughout Albania is documented. Albania’s Annual Transparency Reporting obligations to the international disarmament conventions are timely fulfilled.

description.narrative: Reduced and amalgamated LGUs, able to provide efficent local services to citizens

comment.narrative: The country territorial set up/division with 373 local government s units hinder efficiency of governance and service provision.

- Establishment and capacity building of 61 groups at newly established LGUs level - Assessment/ due diligence of newly established local government units - Guidelines on amalgamation are developed - Profiles of newly established LGUs are designed reflecting changes in the territory. - financial consolidation of 61 LGUs - documentation management of the 61 amalgamated LGUs

provider-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT
UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

description.narrative: 1. New Social Protection and Inclusion Strategy, and M&E Frameworks developed in a participatory way 2. Number of new laws and secondary legislation supported to ensure conformity with the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. 3. Number of municipalities planning, budgeting and providing gender sensitive social services to most at risk populations 4. Number of policies and plans on social services developed or improved with participation of Civil Society Organizations and marginalized groups 5. Number of regional coordination committees established for participatory social impact assessment 6. Criteria and guidelines in place for adapting social and public services to the specific needs of Roma/Egyptian populations

comment.narrative: 1. National social protection and social inclusion strategies due to expire in 2013 2. No laws and secondary legislation in place; concept of accessibility not understood as a cross-cutting issue 3. Number of Local Government units with inclusive social policy services in place is not known 4. No regional coordination committees for participatory social impact assessment 5, No Criteria and guidelines in place for adapting social services to the specific needs of Roma/Egyptian populations

1. Social Inclusion Policy Document 2015-2020 (including Indicators, Baselines and Targets for Social Inclusion Policies 2014-2020) finalized and endorsed by the government 2. Social exclusion profiles and policies for PWD and Roma developed, 3. By-laws of the law on Inclusion of and Accessibility for Persons with Disabilities elaborated through consultative process 4. Social Housing Strategy/ action plan (from social inclusion perspective) developed and endorsed by the government. A set of appropriate tools for the implementation and monitoring is in place 5. At least 2 demonstrative projects developed and implemented to accommodate the needs of persons with disabilities for education and integration

description.narrative: UNDP's vision is to orient work skill forecasting, integrating entrepreneurship training in VET and employment programmes and extension of employment and skills development services to rural areas
The overall goal of the project is that “more young women and men in urban and rural areas in Albania are employed or self-employed.”
policy, planning and administration

1.Operational plan in place and at least 2 new measures designed. 2. Self-employment measure designed. 3. Feasibility study carried out. 4. Elements of quality assurance identified. 5. Updated national list of occupations in place and occupational descriptions finalized.

comment.narrative: 1. 7 employment promotion measures currently implemented by NES; however, no operational plan in place. 2. No self-employment measure in place. 3. Several pilots carried out, however, no nation-wide model of work-based learning in place. 4. Elements of quality assurance piloted; however, no standards, tools and mechanisms implemented system wide. 5. National list of occupations established in 2009. 200 occupational descriptions elaborated. Over 320 remaining.

1. Operational plan of employment promotion measures developed and at least 2 new measures designed 2. Self-employment programme designed 3. Feasibility study on work-based learning models carried out 4. Models of quality assurance assessed and discussions on an Albanian model of quality assurance commence among relevant actors. 5. National list of occupations updated and occupational descriptions developed for all occupational levels.

title.narrative: Enabling transbound. coop.&IWRM in the Ext. Drin River B

description.narrative: Enabling transboundary cooperation and integrated water resources management in the extended Drini River Basin
Enabling transboundary cooperation and integrated water resources management in the extended Drini River Basin

The Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis of the Extended Drin River Basin, consistent with the projects in accordance with the WFD in sub-basins, and identifying main issues of transboundary concern and drivers of change, is completed and approved by countries. Information management system containing data gathered through the TDA is established. The Shared Vision contained in the Drin MoU - updated in consistency with the findings of the TDA, and containing indication of environmental quality objectives (horizon 20 years), relevant indicators, and strategic development lines and priorities - is agreed upon by the countries. A Strategic Action Program (SAP with horizon 5 years) consistent with the updated Shared Vision and the Drin MoU, addressing main issues of transboundary concern and containing concrete actions at the national and regional levels, is formulated. The three Drin Core Group (DCG) Expert Working Groups (EWG) become fully operational making it possible for the DCG to assume the full range of responsibilities stemming from the Drin MoU and act as a Joint Commission. Inter-ministerial Committees (or equivalent bodies) are established in each project country tasked with the coordination of country response to guidance of the DCG. A Strategic Action Program (SAP with horizon 5 years) is adopted by the countries. DCG members, DCG working group members, water and land managers, policy makers and other practitioners are trained in surface/groundwater management, IWRM, implementation of international policy instruments (WFD, UNECE Water Convention), and other relevant disciplines and technologies. Program of Pilot Demonstrations, responding to the Drin MoU approved by countries during inception period is implemented resulting in: Management Plan for Ohrid Lake is prepared; Integrated modelling tool is developed assisting in: appropriate quality for treated effluents and appropriate wastewater management solution for Shkodra city in Albania to be determined.

comment.narrative: Information and data related to the management of Drin Basin are dispersed among countries and institutions. Countries adopting fragmented approach to water resources utilization and environmental protection with little consideration of transboundary implications and freshwater ecosystems sustainability. A Shared Vision for the management of the Drin Basin has been developed through a multi-stakeholders process and adopted by the Drin Riparians as part of the Drin MoU. Nevertheless, this Shared Vision needs to be developed further to include environmental quality objectives and relevant indicators. Lack of an overarching basin-wide science based framework for the implementation of the medium and long term priority actions in view of achieving the overall aims and objectives of the Drin MoU, and of the updated Vision hinders the formulation of coherent policies, legislative reforms and identification of investments targeted to the sustainable utilization of the Basin’s water resources and dependent ecosystems, and their integrated management. A Basin Management Plan is not in place in Lake Ohrid; the preparation, in accordance to the WFD, of a basin management plan for a shared water body is not tested in the Drin Basin. Shkodra city is a pollution hotspot affecting areas of paramount ecological importance. Illegal fishing exerts pressure to the fisheries in Shkoder/Skadar, and despite the continuous efforts, institutional capacities are weak to address the issue. Level of public participation in decision-making is unclear in all countries, with efforts being made to introduce/implement legislation leading to increased stakeholder involvement and public participation. Gender issues not yet considered. Public awareness of natural resource sustainability issues and of water governance and management is generally scarce.

(i) building consensus among countries on key transboundary concerns and drivers of change, including climate variability and change, reached through joint fact finding; (ii) facilitating the agreement on a shared vision and on a program of priority actions deemed necessary to achieve the vision; (iii) strengthening technical and institutional capacities.

description.narrative: 1. Number of self-employment opportunities created for women; 2. 2015 perception study on gender equality and women’s successful integration into the labor market

comment.narrative: 1. Women represent 43.4% of labor force and own 28.5% enterprises; 2. Women literacy on economic, property and family rights is inconsiderable;

1. 4 self-employment opportunities created in four regions of the country for particular poor, marginalized and vulnerable women, particularly the ones that are de jure or de facto heads of households; 2. Women from semi-rural and rural areas, interest groups/women NGOs in 6 regions in the country are literate on their economic, property and family rights.

Anti-corruption and Rule of Law (ACROL) Programme

description.narrative: Anti-corruption and Rule of Law (ACROL) Programme

title.narrative: Anti-corruption and Rule of Law (ACROL) Programme
Anti-corruption and Rule of Law (ACROL) Programme
Anti-corruption and Rule of Law (ACROL) Programme

description.narrative: Technical assistance on implementation as well as advocacy and awareness rising on structural reforms and tangible measures in fighting corruption and enforcing the rule of law.

Online interface upgraded Automated reports production enabled Surveys on relevance of the portal carried out % of citizens entrusting the relevance of the portal increased 35 designated officials trained on relevant legislation, procedures and management of cases

comment.narrative: In February 2015, the Government launched a first of its kind anti-corruption portal. The portal is a novelty in Albania, a unique interface where citizens can report cases of corruption occurring across public institutions. This new initiative merges into one central website the former 22 websites of different institutions and agencies and provides for a “user friendly” way to denounce corruptive practices. A mid-term plan is to have a unique green line for the same purpose.

The SW / Database Information System is enhanced/developed and functioning by end August 2015. All templates of formats for the periodic reporting developed by end August 2015. Survey on public perceived relevance of the A/C portal carried out in May and November 2015 SW/HW capacities further developed. The staff of the on-line Portal Supporting Unit has completed the trainings on the use of SW application by end July 2015. Designated officials trained on relevant legislation, procedures and management of denounced cases, monitoring and reporting by end September 2015 A manual of operations for the use of SW/Database application developed by end August 2015.

description.narrative: Strengthening disaster resilience of at risk LGUs and communities in Albania

title.narrative: ProDoc Strengthening Disaster Resilience at Risk
QPR July 2015 1 Strengthening resilience LGU ATlas 04120

description.narrative: PDNA exercise targeting assessment of impacts and planning recovery and reconstruction in a number of sectors, notably agriculture.

For the first time a government-led, donor-assisted PDNA conducted in Albania Effects of floods on social/community/households functions and processes adequately assessed Consolidated data on cross-cutting issues such as gender, DRR and environment

comment.narrative: No standardized damage and loss assessment methodology No human recovery needs assessment previously conducted No consolidated data on cross-cutting issues such as gender, DRR and environment
Government-led donor-assisted PDNA Capacity development requirements identified Gender specific vulnerability during the assessment process
Government-led donor-assisted PDNA conducted Organic integration of gender specific vulnerability during the assessment process

description.narrative: Capacity for environmental monitoring and information management in Albania
Establishment of Albania’s Environmental Information Management and Monitoring System

By the end of the project, key government staff in at least three offices and Rio Conventions experts from the three conventions use the EIMMS and/or the reports it generates in the course of their official duties Global caliber environmental indicators and baseline information have been established for all key fields in the protected areas sector Use of the EIMMS documented in the formulation of at least three reports to Rio Conventions Visualization of data used by project partners to raise awareness of at least two international and three national issues

comment.narrative: Government environmental policy priorities are not necessarily aligned with current environmental monitoring The EIMS system is highly theoretical, not seen as applicable Lack of methodology and standards for some key biodiversity indicators. QA/QC practices are not operational to an extent where there is high confidence in the precision of the data collected, or even a sense of its reliability. Lack of standardization in methodologies and indicators hinder the development of year-on-year analysis Data not packaged for different non-technical audiences (e.g. policy-makers, the media, and the public). Low prevalence of good practice in data visualization techniques Research may not reach the communities or resource managers in the areas it covers (e.g. fishing license data is not shared with coastal protected area managers) Low awareness of citizens regarding basic measures of environmental quality No standardized protocol for archiving environmental data No centralized location for data archiving; archiving is spread across the government, donor, and CSO sectors.

Assessment of needs and resources available to achieve more cost-effective and relevant data collection and maintenance by better identification of users and their information needs at the local and national level

description.narrative: The project interventions imply mainly infrastructure rehabilitation such as reconstruction of embankments, dams and river protection; repairing and/or upgrading of damaged irrigation and drainage canals; etc.

The overall objective is to strengthen resilience and disaster risk preparedness and prevention in southeast Albania in line with the post-disaster needs assessment following the February 2015 floods.

No. flood protection built environment restored in priority areas No. studies on disaster social impact and risk scenarios for building national and local capacities to address social and gender-based vulnerabilities and mitigate environmental and economic losses. No. flood protection built environment rehabilitated and put back to operation Assessment of impact of floods on vulnerable groups and their views on ways to cope with such risks. No. studies/reports carried out No. workshops and participants No. infrastructures rehabilitated Study on floods social impact Awareness raising targeting local authorities Vulnerability to climate change and other major disasters assessed for specified vulnerable groups, including gender considerations

comment.narrative: Obsolete, poorly maintained and damaged flood protection infrastructures Lack of technical studies and thus preparedness to cope with future risks and integrate such considerations into development agendas. Key flood protection infrastructures damaged, exposing about 26,000 ha of agricultural land at risk for next rainy season. PDNA 2015 No prior social assessment on floods impact with such a disaggregation detail; no inputs to local decision making from this angle.

17 prioritized as most urgent interventions to be completed possibly prior to the next rainy season. Four technical reports / assessments on social vulnerabilities and Disaster risk scenarios developed One assessment report on social impact of floods focusing on four municipalities
